tags: I love bran with all my heart
summary: Meera began to cry.Bran hated being crippled then.  "Don't cry," he said. He wanted to put his arms around her, hold her tight...
body:
Meera began to cry.Bran hated being crippled then. 

“Don’t cry,” he said. He wanted to put his arms around her, hold her tight the way his mother used to hold him back at Winterfell when he’d hurt himself. She was right there, only a few feet from him, but so far out of reach it might have been a hundred leagues. To touch her he would need to pull himself along the ground with his hands, dragging his legs behind him  [..].

                                                         - A Dance With Dragons, Bran III


Bran is  such a sweet boy wanting to comfort Meera and my heart breaks that he’s not able to do so due to his disability. I can only imagine how he feels on that scene. My poor boy :/

summary: “We’ll take the horse too, said another of them, a woman shorter than Robb, with a broad flat face and lank yellow hair. “Get...
caption:
“We’ll take the horse too, said another of them, a woman shorter than Robb, with a broad flat face and lank yellow hair. “Get down, and be quick about it.” A knife slid from her sleeve into her hand, its age jagged as a saw.

“No,” Bran blurted. “I can’t”

Game of Thrones, Chapter 37

tags: game of thrones characters as greek mythological figures
summary: Game of Thrones // Greek Mythology Part 2 - Men of House Stark Eddard Stark // Dike, God of Justice Robert Stark // Ares, God of...
body:
Game of Thrones // Greek Mythology

Part 2 - Men of House Stark

Eddard Stark // Dike, God of Justice

Robert Stark // Ares, God of War

Jon Snow // Prometheus, God of Forethought, savior of Mankind

Brandon Stark // Hypnos, God of Sleep and Visions

Rickon Stark // Pan, God of the Woods and Wilderness

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: DON’T REPOST MY ART. Share from my own accounts.Where not possible  ASK FOR PERMISSION, tag me, give credit I love love love...
caption:
DON’T REPOST MY ART. Share from my own accounts.Where not possible  ASK FOR PERMISSION, tag me, give credit

I love love love Jaime and Brienne <3.

So I had this sketch of them…and I felt like something was missing…or someone…

The erection part is based on this book quote:

‘Jaime caught a glimpse of the thick blonde bush at the juncture of her thighs as she climbed out. She was much hairier than his sister. Absurdly, he felt his cock stir beneath the bathwater. Now I know I have been too long away from Cersei. He averted his eyes, troubled by his body’s response.’

(Jaime V, A Storm of Swords)

Brienne remembering the bath scene:

‘The bathhouse had been thick with the steam rising off the water, and Jaime had come walking through that mist naked as his name day, looking half a corpse and half a god. He climbed into the tub with me, she remembered, blushing. She seized a chunk of hard lye soap and scrubbed under her arms, trying to call up Renly’s face again. ‘

(A Feast for Crows, Brienne II)

The polishing part is my input, but Brienne does think a lot about him. Ser Jaime this, Ser Jaime that etc. His name appears 41 times in Brienne’s  8 chapters.

……………………………………………………..

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AlcoholicRattleSnakeArt/

VK: https://vk.com/alcoholicrattlesnake

summary: Part of him wanted to shout at them for leaving him, and another part wanted to cry. He was almost a man grown, though, so he...
text: Part of him wanted to shout at them for leaving him, and another part wanted to cry. He was almost a man grown, though, so he said nothing.
source: George R. R. Martin “A Dance with Dragons”

blog.name: gameofthronestldr
blog.title: Game of Thrones;tldr
blog.description: I love Game of Thrones, both the books and the HBO series. I would like to explore characters, places, etc. in a shortened as possible way (hence the tldr). This will include both information from the books and show.

tags: a song of ice and fire
title: Brandon Stark
body:
“Old stories are like old friends. You have to visit them from time to time” - Brandon Stark

Born: 290 AC at Winterfell

Hair: Auburn

Eye Color: Blue

Features: Crippled, unable to walk

Culture: Northmen 

Father: Eddard Stark

Mother: Catelyn Stark

Siblings:

  1. Robb Stark
  2. Sansa Stark
  3. Arya Stark
  4. Rickon Stark
  5. Jon Snow (paternal cousin raised as bastard half-brother)

Titles: 

  1. Prince (formerly)
  2. Acting Lord of Winterfell (formerly) 

Aliases:

  1. Bran Stark
  2. Little Lord
  3. Bran the Broken
  4. The Winged Wolf
  5. Three-Eyed Raven

Allegiance:

  1. House Stark
  2. Three-Eyed Crow

Religion: Old Gods of the Forest 

Direwolf: Summer

History

Brandon Stark, commonly called Bran, is the fourth child and second son of Eddard and Catelyn Stark. 

Bran was born and raised at Winterfell. He has an older brother Robb, a younger brother Rickon, two older sisters Sansa and Arya, and an older “bastard half-brother”, Jon Snow, who is actually Bran’s first cousin by his aunt Lyanna Stark. Bran was named for Ned’s elder brother, Brandon, who was brutally executed by the Mad King along with Bran’s paternal grandfather Rickard Stark. He is only called “Brandon” by his mother when he has done something wrong. Bran dreams of being a knight of the Kingsguard, and his favorite hobby is climbing the walls of Winterfell, using its old rooftops and passageways to get around.

Bran is a warg and currently the new Three-Eyed Raven, using his supernatural gifts to assist his family in the war against the White Walkers.

Appearance and Personality

Bran has his mother’s coloring, with the thick auburn hair and deep blue eyes associated with House Tully.

Bran is a pleasant young boy, regarded fondly by the people of Winterfell. Before the incident of his fall, Bran was an extremely curious and adventurous boy. He was noted by his mother, and by his brother Robb, to have done a great amount of climbing around the walls of Winterfell and having never fallen, showing a considerable amount of bravery on his part. His curiosity was in large part what led to his fall in the first place, since he was drawn into the encounter between Jaime and Cersei out of sheer curiosity as to what was happening. After his fall, Bran’s rapidly worsening situation forced him to become far more solemn and apprehensive than the cheerful child he had once been. After words Bran had it in him to be a good lord in his own right, as proven by his brief tenure as acting Lord of Winterfell when Robb left to fight Tywin Lannister.

Upon meeting Jojen Reed, Bran proved capable of accepting the powers that he possessed, showing an open mind on his part, even if such a thing set him apart from companions like Osha. He became almost unbreakably determined to meet the Three-Eyed Raven that kept coming to him in his dreams, even if it meant separating from his brother Rickon and, later on, from Jon Snow. When Bran finally reached the Three-Eyed Raven, one of the first things he pressed the Three-Eyed Raven about is whether or not Bran could walk again, and is briefly disappointed when told that he will never walk again.

After growing up under the tutelage of the Three-Eyed Raven, Bran maintains his curious nature, especially when he and the Raven visit Winterfell; his curiosity piques when he sees his long-dead aunt Lyanna. Bran is disappointed by the prospect of returning to the real world. Later on, Bran expresses confusion when witnessing the duel at the Tower of Joy, especially when his young father started losing the duel - this confusion turned to horror when he realized that Arthur Dayne lost only because Howland Reed blindsided him, having been told all his life that Ned ultimately killed the man in an honorable duel. This horror resurfaced when he realized that the Children of the Forest were responsible for the creation of the White Walkers, only to be silenced when Leaf cited the havoc caused by men to be the main reason for this course of action. He also shows incredulity at what his own powers can accomplish, as shown when he realizes how he is responsible for breaking Hodor’s mind in the first place.

Upon returning from Beyond the Wall, Bran’s personality has changed significantly, as a result of the expansion his powers have taken since the battle at the Cave of the Three-Eyed Raven. He has become extremely calm to a fault, to the point of being almost detached from everyone else around him. Having become the new Three-Eyed Raven, Bran has been given access to many more events, which he explains several times, so much that Bran becomes aware of almost anything, for example the wedding between his sister Sansa and Ramsay Bolton, and even the conversation between Littlefinger and Varys. He also shows a rather dangerous and threatening side, as evidenced by his deadpan recital of Chaos is a ladder to Petyr Baelish, outright showing that he knows how treacherous Petyr is and what he has done against House Stark in the past, but also suggesting that Petyr is unable to manipulate him. Also, Bran shows himself to have become almost wiser than he was before, ultimately not accepting the Valyrian steel dagger that Littlefinger gives him, citing that it would be useless for a cripple, but at the same time obviously not trusting the gifts that the man gives him. However, Bran is not truly omniscient, as he still needs to witness events in order to find out about them, as shown by his surprise when he heard that Rhaegar and Lyanna were secretly married.

Skills

Bran Stark is one of a few characters known to possess magical abilities.

Greensight - also called simply “The Sight”, is the ability to receive prophetic visions, starting off in the form of dreams. Bran’s powers extend far beyond simply viewing events unfold; he is capable of influencing past events, though he cannot change what was predestined to occur already.
Warg - Bran is a warg, a human who can send his consciousness into the mind of an animal, to see through its eyes and control its body as if it were his own. Jojen Reed states that this is a different, though related, ability to the Sight. Though he still needs training, Bran is inherently a very powerful warg, even able to enter the mind of another human, something the wargs among the wildlings are unable and unwilling to do. Bran has already become skilled at entering the mind of his direwolf Summer, in which he is a dangerous fighter, capable of dispatching several wildlings or wights, and uses Hodor to perform more complicated tasks or to supplement Summer’s fighting capacity.

  • Skinchanging with a Heart tree, a Weirwood with a face carved in it by the Children of the Forest, allows Bran to have vivid visions of past, present, and future events, including those far away from himself. While in the visions, Bran is once again capable of walking.

reblog.comment:

He also shows a rather dangerous and threatening side, as evidenced by his deadpan recital of Chaos is a ladder to Petyr Baelish, outright showing that he knows how treacherous Petyr is and what he has done against House Stark in the past, but also suggesting that Petyr is unable to manipulate him. Also, Bran shows himself to have become almost wiser than he was before, ultimately not accepting the Valyrian steel dagger that Littlefinger gives him, citing that it would be useless for a cripple, but at the same time obviously not trusting the gifts that the man gives him. However, Bran is not truly omniscient, as he still needs to witness events in order to find out about them, as shown by his surprise when he heard that Rhaegar and Lyanna were secretly married.

Skills

Bran Stark is one of a few characters known to possess magical abilities.

Greensight - also called simply “The Sight”, is the ability to receive prophetic visions, starting off in the form of dreams. Bran’s powers extend far beyond simply viewing events unfold; he is capable of influencing past events, though he cannot change what was predestined to occur already.
Warg - Bran is a warg, a human who can send his consciousness into the mind of an animal, to see through its eyes and control its body as if it were his own. Jojen Reed states that this is a different, though related, ability to the Sight. Though he still needs training, Bran is inherently a very powerful warg, even able to enter the mind of another human, something the wargs among the wildlings are unable and unwilling to do. Bran has already become skilled at entering the mind of his direwolf Summer, in which he is a dangerous fighter, capable of dispatching several wildlings or wights, and uses Hodor to perform more complicated tasks or to supplement Summer’s fighting capacity.

  • Skinchanging with a Heart tree, a Weirwood with a face carved in it by the Children of the Forest, allows Bran to have vivid visions of past, present, and future events, including those far away from himself. While in the visions, Bran is once again capable of walking.

trail.content_raw:
“Old stories are like old friends. You have to visit them from time to time” - Brandon Stark

Born: 290 AC at Winterfell

Hair: Auburn

Eye Color: Blue

Features: Crippled, unable to walk

Culture: Northmen 

Father: Eddard Stark

Mother: Catelyn Stark

Siblings:

  1. Robb Stark
  2. Sansa Stark
  3. Arya Stark
  4. Rickon Stark
  5. Jon Snow (paternal cousin raised as bastard half-brother)

Titles: 

  1. Prince (formerly)
  2. Acting Lord of Winterfell (formerly) 

Aliases:

  1. Bran Stark
  2. Little Lord
  3. Bran the Broken
  4. The Winged Wolf
  5. Three-Eyed Raven

Allegiance:

  1. House Stark
  2. Three-Eyed Crow

Religion: Old Gods of the Forest 

Direwolf: Summer

History

Brandon Stark, commonly called Bran, is the fourth child and second son of Eddard and Catelyn Stark. 

Bran was born and raised at Winterfell. He has an older brother Robb, a younger brother Rickon, two older sisters Sansa and Arya, and an older “bastard half-brother”, Jon Snow, who is actually Bran’s first cousin by his aunt Lyanna Stark. Bran was named for Ned’s elder brother, Brandon, who was brutally executed by the Mad King along with Bran’s paternal grandfather Rickard Stark. He is only called “Brandon” by his mother when he has done something wrong. Bran dreams of being a knight of the Kingsguard, and his favorite hobby is climbing the walls of Winterfell, using its old rooftops and passageways to get around.

Bran is a warg and currently the new Three-Eyed Raven, using his supernatural gifts to assist his family in the war against the White Walkers.

Appearance and Personality

Bran has his mother’s coloring, with the thick auburn hair and deep blue eyes associated with House Tully.

Bran is a pleasant young boy, regarded fondly by the people of Winterfell. Before the incident of his fall, Bran was an extremely curious and adventurous boy. He was noted by his mother, and by his brother Robb, to have done a great amount of climbing around the walls of Winterfell and having never fallen, showing a considerable amount of bravery on his part. His curiosity was in large part what led to his fall in the first place, since he was drawn into the encounter between Jaime and Cersei out of sheer curiosity as to what was happening. After his fall, Bran’s rapidly worsening situation forced him to become far more solemn and apprehensive than the cheerful child he had once been. After words Bran had it in him to be a good lord in his own right, as proven by his brief tenure as acting Lord of Winterfell when Robb left to fight Tywin Lannister.

Upon meeting Jojen Reed, Bran proved capable of accepting the powers that he possessed, showing an open mind on his part, even if such a thing set him apart from companions like Osha. He became almost unbreakably determined to meet the Three-Eyed Raven that kept coming to him in his dreams, even if it meant separating from his brother Rickon and, later on, from Jon Snow. When Bran finally reached the Three-Eyed Raven, one of the first things he pressed the Three-Eyed Raven about is whether or not Bran could walk again, and is briefly disappointed when told that he will never walk again.

After growing up under the tutelage of the Three-Eyed Raven, Bran maintains his curious nature, especially when he and the Raven visit Winterfell; his curiosity piques when he sees his long-dead aunt Lyanna. Bran is disappointed by the prospect of returning to the real world. Later on, Bran expresses confusion when witnessing the duel at the Tower of Joy, especially when his young father started losing the duel - this confusion turned to horror when he realized that Arthur Dayne lost only because Howland Reed blindsided him, having been told all his life that Ned ultimately killed the man in an honorable duel. This horror resurfaced when he realized that the Children of the Forest were responsible for the creation of the White Walkers, only to be silenced when Leaf cited the havoc caused by men to be the main reason for this course of action. He also shows incredulity at what his own powers can accomplish, as shown when he realizes how he is responsible for breaking Hodor’s mind in the first place.

Upon returning from Beyond the Wall, Bran’s personality has changed significantly, as a result of the expansion his powers have taken since the battle at the Cave of the Three-Eyed Raven. He has become extremely calm to a fault, to the point of being almost detached from everyone else around him. Having become the new Three-Eyed Raven, Bran has been given access to many more events, which he explains several times, so much that Bran becomes aware of almost anything, for example the wedding between his sister Sansa and Ramsay Bolton, and even the conversation between Littlefinger and Varys. He also shows a rather dangerous and threatening side, as evidenced by his deadpan recital of Chaos is a ladder to Petyr Baelish, outright showing that he knows how treacherous Petyr is and what he has done against House Stark in the past, but also suggesting that Petyr is unable to manipulate him. Also, Bran shows himself to have become almost wiser than he was before, ultimately not accepting the Valyrian steel dagger that Littlefinger gives him, citing that it would be useless for a cripple, but at the same time obviously not trusting the gifts that the man gives him. However, Bran is not truly omniscient, as he still needs to witness events in order to find out about them, as shown by his surprise when he heard that Rhaegar and Lyanna were secretly married.

Skills

Bran Stark is one of a few characters known to possess magical abilities.

Greensight - also called simply “The Sight”, is the ability to receive prophetic visions, starting off in the form of dreams. Bran’s powers extend far beyond simply viewing events unfold; he is capable of influencing past events, though he cannot change what was predestined to occur already.
Warg - Bran is a warg, a human who can send his consciousness into the mind of an animal, to see through its eyes and control its body as if it were his own. Jojen Reed states that this is a different, though related, ability to the Sight. Though he still needs training, Bran is inherently a very powerful warg, even able to enter the mind of another human, something the wargs among the wildlings are unable and unwilling to do. Bran has already become skilled at entering the mind of his direwolf Summer, in which he is a dangerous fighter, capable of dispatching several wildlings or wights, and uses Hodor to perform more complicated tasks or to supplement Summer’s fighting capacity.

  • Skinchanging with a Heart tree, a Weirwood with a face carved in it by the Children of the Forest, allows Bran to have vivid visions of past, present, and future events, including those far away from himself. While in the visions, Bran is once again capable of walking.

blog.name: tatticstudio55
blog.title: pro jonerys who likes healthy debates

title: The Bran quote/vision
body:
@soleilpirate

“ Finally he looked north. He saw the Wall shining like blue crystal, and his bastard brother Jon sleeping alone in a cold bed, his skin growing pale and hard as the memory of all warmth fled from him. And he looked past the Wall, past endless forests cloaked in snow, past the frozen shore and the great blue-white rivers of ice and the dead plains where nothing grew or lived. North and north and north he looked, to the curtain of light at the end of the world, and then beyond that curtain. He looked deep into the heart of winter, and then he cried out, afraid, and the heat of his tears burned on his cheeks.”

Hum. A hard nut to crack. 

Might have something to do with ice magic. It reminds me of when Jon had woken up outside of Craster’s keep, in ACOK, to find the surrounding forest sort of “suspended in time”, covered in tiny shiny crystals and stuff, and marveling at how magical it looked. Back then, the magic faded once people around him started waking up, almost like human presences were, by themselves, enough to crush or dissipate the magic. That might explain why, in Bran’s vision, the absence of living human being (or any living being) is so strongly insinuated:

shining like blue crystal (…)  endless forests cloaked in snow, past the frozen shore and the great blue-white rivers of ice and the dead plains where nothing grew or lived.

The “shining blue crystal” on the Wall also reminds me of the blue flower in a chink of ice, and the forests “cloaked” in snow might be a wink to a marriage of sorts (snow “cloaking” the bride). 

There might also be an ambiguity between looking/going “past” something (as in, beyond), and going in the past, or seeing/witnessing/recalling something that happened a long time ago:

the memory of all warmth fled from him. And he looked past the Wall, past endless forests cloaked in snow, past the frozen shore and the great blue-white rivers of ice. 

I’m not too familiar with that tale, but you know the one of the LC who married a female Other? It doesn’t necessarily point out to Jon repeating that story (I’m pretty sure it doesn’t), but if we put the pieces together, this vision brings up (to recapitulate):

-The matter of ice magic on/beyond the Wall

-A LC (Jon Snow in the vision, although it might be a stand-in for someone else) “cold and pale”, and sleeping alone in a cold bed (there’s some odd matrimonial undertones to this…)

-The snow cloaking the forest: the forest beyond the Wall is called the “haunted forest”, thus giving a somewhat sinister aspect to the “bride”.

-Something that might’ve taken place in the past

There’s also this ominous line:  deep into the heart of winter, and then he cried out, afraid

(Might have something to do with when Leaf thrust the dragonglass piece into the heart of the first human-turned WW?)

Anyway, this might be complete bollocks, but I think the vision relates to the story (or stories) and origins of the WW? 

@oadara @just-a-crazy-lass @instantbouquetface-me @tomakeitbeautifultolive

@luvd80s2 @winelover1989 @mhysaofdragons @ladyofdragonstone @iheartdandelions @mysnowdragons

summary: "There was a shout from the courtyard below. Prince Tommen was rolling in the dust trying to get up and failing. All the padding...
caption: “There was a shout from the courtyard below. Prince Tommen was rolling in the dust trying to get up and failing. All the padding made him look like a turtle on it’s back. Bran was standing over him with upraised sword, ready to whack him again once he regained his feet. The men began to laugh.”

blog.description: Writing at the speed of the race course paradox.

summary: Why is it that the current mentors of the young Starks (LF, The Faceless Men and Bloodraven), the ones meant to train them for...
question: Why is it that the current mentors of the young Starks (LF, The Faceless Men and Bloodraven), the ones meant to train them for their part in the endgame and beyond, are all shitty in some way? Their goals range from unjust at best to devastating at worst.
answer:
To be fair, Bloodraven’s on the right side of things, it’s just that his moral supervision of the child he’s training up to serious supernatural power is severely lacking. Uncle Ben he is not.

The answer, though, is conflict. 

If Littlefinger really did see Sansa as a daughter and only as a daughter, if he was sincere in his love for her and Catelyn, where’s Sansa’s internal conflict? Everything’s external: will Sansa regain Winterfell? Will she go North in time to meaningfully aid her family? She never has to ask herself who she is and who she wants to be. Ditto Arya, though it’s harder to see how she could learn those particular skills from morally above-board sources. Uh, say she was learning fighting from some old soldiers and moonlighting with mummers, go with that. If she did that, she never has to ask herself who she is and who she wants to be, either, and again the conflict would be coming only from external factors. And Bran - without going the wrong way, his powers turn into a supernatural slugfest, rather than an examination of the responsibility that comes with that power.
